contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox MP |honorific-prefix = |name = Hilton Dawson |honorific-suffix = |image = |constituency_MP = [[Lancaster and Wyre (UK Parliament constituency)|Lancaster and Wyre]] |parliament = |majority = |term_start = 1 May 1997 |term_end = 5 May 2005 |predecessor = [[Boundary Commissions (United Kingdom)|Constituency Established]] |successor = [[Ben Wallace (UK politician)|Ben Wallace]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|09|30|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Newbiggin by the Sea, Northumberland]] |death_date = |death_place = |restingplace = |birthname = |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] |party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] |otherparty = |spouse = Susan Williams |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = [[Lancaster University]], [[University of Warwick]] |occupation = |profession = |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |website = }} '''Thomas Hilton Dawson''', known as '''Hilton Dawson''', (born 30 September 1953 in [[Stannington, Northumberland]]) was the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] [[member of Parliament]] for the [[Lancashire]] constituency of [[Lancaster and Wyre (UK Parliament constituency)|Lancaster and Wyre]] from [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997]] until 2005. ==Early life== He is the son of Harry Dawson and his wife Sally, both teachers. He attended Ashington County Grammar School (now known as [http://www.ashingtonhigh.northumberland.sch.uk Ashington High School]) on ''Green Lane'' in Ashington. At the [[University of Warwick]], he gained a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in Politics and Philosophy in 1975. From the [[Lancaster University]], he gained a [http://www.lancs.ac.uk/fass/apsocsci/prospective/ma.htm Diploma in Social Work]. He worked as a Social Work Manager from 1983–97, involving Children's Homes, [[Foster care|Fostering]] and Adoption, and [[Day care]]. ==Parliamentary career== In 2004 he announced he would not be seeking re-election at the next General Election, seeking to return to work in children's services – his former career was as a social worker. The local [[Constituency Labour Party]] selected Anne Sacks as its new candidate, but the seat was won by the Conservative Party candidate, [[Ben Wallace (UK politician)|Ben Wallace]], with a 4.5% swing from Labour. ==Life after Parliament== Dawson was CEO of Shaftesbury Young People<ref>[http://www.shaftesbury.org.uk/about/chief-exec/ Shaftesbury Young People website]</ref> In April 2009 he was appointed chief executive of the [[British Association of Social Workers]].<ref>[http://www.communitycare.co.uk/Articles/2009/02/20/110773/hilton-dawson-appointed-chief-executive-of-basw.htm "Former MP to take over from Ian Johnston in April", Community Care, 20 February 2009]</ref> Hilton left BASW in January 2013 and now runs his own company Northumbria People - everybody matters here.www.northumbriapeople.co.uk In March 2013 he published Frank Renner's Bairns - looking at the world through the lives of a Northumbrian Family. Hilton is Chair of the Newbiggin by the Sea Genealogy Project ==Personal life== He married Susan Williams on August 11, 1973. They have two daughters and four grandchildren. He is a supporter of [[Sunderland A.F.C.]]<ref>Thorpe, Martin, 'It's The Pits: Football Diary', [[The Guardian]], 22 November 1997, pA12</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.guardian.co.uk/society/2007/dec/12/parenting ''Guardian'' article December 2007] * [http://www.theyworkforyou.com/mp/hilton_dawson/lancaster_and_wyre They Work For You] * [http://politics.guardian.co.uk/person/0,,-1347,00.html Ask Aristotle] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Dawson, Hilton | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = British politician | DATE OF BIRTH =30 September 1953 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Stannington, Northumberland]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dawson, Hilton}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the United Kingdom Parliament for English constituencies]] [[Category:Labour Party (UK) MPs]] [[Category:UK MPs 1997–2001]] [[Category:UK MPs 2001–2005]] [[Category:People from Ashington]] [[Category:Alumni of Lancaster University]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Warwick]] {{Labour-UK-MP-stub}}
